docs.lead_paragraph: 'Ooooh, I was mad!'' Opal Caples says, recalling the notice from the welfare office. ''They said we had to start working for our welfare check! I said, 'How could they do this to us?' I didn't feel it was right, to take our money -- that's for our children.'' And as a black woman living in Milwaukee's sprawling black ghetto, Caples detected a hidden agenda. No one talked about work rules in the 1930's, when ''welfare was made for middle-class white women,'' she says. ''They're really just targeting the black women.'' A bright, animated, street-smart woman who punctuates her speech with knowing glances -- you know what I'm talking about, her look insists -- Caples is telling her story on the No. 12 bus one July afternoon as it shakes and wheezes down Teutonia Avenue, past the check-cashing counters, liquor stores and lounges. She has dropped her three young daughters with her cousin, Jewel (actually with Jewel's 13-year-old nephew, Little Chuck, since Jewel wasn't around), and before long she'll be toting trash and swabbing toilets in the gastrointestinal lab of a downtown hospital. It's second-shift work and she's unhappy that her girls are asleep by the time the No. 12 shakes home. ''They don't even see me at night,'' she complains.
docs.abstract: Jason DeParle article on people implementing Wisconsin's tough work requirement for welfare recipients; focuses on efforts to keep Milwaukee welfare client Opal Caples at work; notes state, using Federal funds, spends heavily on child care, health care and caseworkers to boost workfare effort; Gov Tommy G Thompson is pushing to raise grant levels to further aid workfare; photos (L)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: The answer, one given for more than four decades, has never changed. Asked how he is or what he is doing, Msgr. Bryan Karvelis, for 41 years a priest at Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church in the Southside neighborhood of Brooklyn, always responds, ''En la lucha.'' The phrase means ''in the struggle,'' and Monsignor Karvelis, the son of Lithuanian and Irish parents and a disciple of the Catholic Worker movement, has fought many of them in his predominantly poor, largely Latino parish of 10,000 people.

headline.main: Anxious Over Welfare Dependency, Pastor Asks if His Help Is Hurting
headline.kicker: A Priest Faces Up to Some Harsh Realities

docs.abstract: Article in series Welfare Neighborhood, on Southside, in Brooklyn; Msgr Bryan Karvelis, for 41 years a priest at Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church, has fought many struggles on behalf of his predominantly poor, largely Latino parish of 10,000 people; past 12 months have been difficult, as Transfiguration and its 67-year-old pastor have confronted new Federal welfare and immigration policies that will curb benefits; Karvelis asserts that for first time in his decades of efforts with immigrants, he can no longer promise a brighter future in America; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It has not made him a popular man. In late July, William Campbell, Danbury's Health Department director, directed the lifeguards at the city's two lakes to enforce the rules: no babies in diapers allowed in the water.

headline.main: No Bathing in Lakes for the Diapered in Danbury

docs.abstract: Danbury, Conn, Health Department director William Campbell banned babies in diapers from swimming areas in late July; baby ban has been in effect for three years, but enforcement has been lax until high bacteria count forced officials to close Lake Kenosia for few days this summer during some warm weather; Campbell says accident by a child still in diapers will add considerably to bacteria count; photo (M)
docs.snippet: It has not made him a popular man.     In late July, William Campbell, Danbury's Health Department director, directed the lifeguards at the city's two lakes to enforce the rules: no babies in diapers allowed in the water.
